comments.commentBody:
I heard the recall actually occurred due to the fact that Synergy, and other brands are not REAL kombucha. It is from Lactobacillus Bacterium, which is from milk (def not kombucha) and S. Boulardii, which is a yeast and age old cure/prevention for diarrhea.

Kombucha has neither of these...something kinda close to S. Boulardi but not really.

Lesson here..READ LABELS!
This was a very low-rent idea. I have seen this sort of thing before by food and restaurant writers. It is always sleezy.

I just arrived from Istanbul, we spent 5 nights in Empress ZOE Hotel. First of all it's not a cheap hotel. The inside of the hotel is beautiful and very elegant, like 4 star hotels. He staff was friendly and helpful - the only problem was that they promised a free taxi transport to the airport in case of 5 nights stay, but I had to ask it more times, they didn't want to give it... I think we received the worst room (No 302) in the hotel, directly under the restaurant and the kitchen, so it was VERY noisy at night and at early dawn too, we couldn't sleep for 5 nights... The room was very elegant and comfortable, the only problem was the terrible view from our window (see pictures)... The air conditioner is strange, when you turn it on, it's frozen, but if you don't use it, it's very hot in the room. The restaurant is nice and the breakfast was good. The entire hotel is very clean! But the outside of the hotel is very dirty, the neighborhood is bad... The hotel is about 1 km from the main attractions, but there are so many other hotels that are closer to the monuments. I recommend everybody to eat at the hotel, because the food is good and there are reasonable prices, but the restaurants near the hotel are expensive and disgusting... I think this hotel is too overestimated in these reviews, for this price I would expect more from a hotel, not enough to be elegant inside. But first and last I recommend it.FOUR tips I have for people staying at the İSTANBUL OLD CİTY HOTELS
1: From airport don't get taxi or shuttle bus, which can cost up to 20euros. Get the metro (M1) to Zeytinburnu, about 6 stops. All trams and transport uses tokens, which costs 1.5 Turkish liras, and you can get this at every station via the vending machines. At Zeytinburnu, change to tram for sultanahmet
2: Don't have dinner in the area round the hotel. All the restaurants serves the same foods and charges about the same money. Instead, eat up in Taksim, which you get to by the same tram you came in on, across the bridge. Up there, where all the night clubs/bars/shopping are, you’ll find a better choice of foods, much better atmosphere and here's the important thing, usually 1/3 to up to 1/2 the price you pay in the restaurants round the hotel
3:Single girls traveling alone will likely get a lot of male attention. It's usually quite harmless--I never felt harassed by it--but it can be a nuisance.

One way to limit this is to buy or borrow a wedding ring, which will cut down on the requests for dinner or a drink or a walk in the park. Some guys can get overly touchy-feely, like the owner of a carpet store just outside the Arasta Bazaar who decided to whisk me into his store. A lot of them call your attention solely for the purpose of making a sale, of course, but *some* of them can get overly familiar.
4: Be careful walking around late at night, too. The police may sometimes question people out late at night and this can be quite a scare.

The truth is neither team showed much "jogo bonito". If anything, it was Mexico who created some play, not Argentina. It was unfortunate that they got that goal, just like England's disallowed one. I guess the refs are not at their best.
Win some, lose some England.  Funny all the outrage about the call in this game, but not the call against Mexico in the second game.
WORLD CUP 2014! Here we come!
From all of the shots ESPN has shown of him in the dugout, I thought Beckham WAS coaching England...
The slovak nation is small albeit, but this is a team that really is a national team, nobody immigrates to Slovenska!!!

I was hoping you'd take this issue up George. Blown calls can totally change the course and outcome of key games, and have a cascading impact on a country's failure or success at the World Cup. Otherwise, they're no big deal...(kidding).

Blatter is rumored to think that controversy over referee decisions is good for the game because it triggers passionate debate. One can say the same thing about hooliganism, racism, doping, and the other ills that FIFA has clamped down on. Somehow the fans still enjoy the game without having to debate these subjects too.

FIFA seems more entrenched than the former Apartheid govt. of South Africa. they should take a cue from the host country -- change is good.

As I understand it, 74-year old Sepp Blatter, the head of FIFA, has been the stumbling block to the adoption of new technology. He should imitate his country's team, and step down for a much younger man, more open to new ideas. Subjective foul calls, or borderline offside calls are part of the game, but totally wrong calls, as in both matches today, should not be.

The big issue is, FIFA cannot run a world cup without trouble at the most basic level, running a fair match.  This isn't that hard.  Review all goals.  Done.  No one will argue with any of the dives and other flopping.  We need fair goals.

@masayaNYC and gong

Oh come'on, the bookmakers are not part of any xenophobic media swarm--they're bookmakers. You don't need to think Capello was at fault (I don't) to know that he's not going to be staying long. The English chew up all its soccer celebrities and digests them fast. It's a hyperventilating dogpile that's going to include the players, not a conspiracy.

I noticed this a little late, Roberto, but osmium can be octavalent.
http://snurl.com/octavalent

@Steve I
Don't be too quick to criticize Arthur118. He seems to be offended by the use of a made-up word (what he calls a "trendy trash phrase"), not the fact that it targets a specific ethnic group.
And Arthur -- I didn't know the word "Jewfro" was well known enough outside of the Jewish community to be an accepted slang term, but it's one that gets used often in my house. Seeing it in the puzzle cracked my kids up!
BTW, does it need to be capitalized?

I'm always amazed when people make righteous statements like "The people we are fighting . . . do not value life as we do.".

I am certain that our "enemies", like all humans, value "life" as much as we Americans do. It is the reason why they are fighting so hard to eject us from their countries.

If foreign armies invaded US soil and annihilated US society using the same methods that we've used overseas, the average American might suddenly have a lot more empathy for those countries and lives we've destroyed.

We've been deceived by the government and the press about the real reasons for initiating the wars in Iraq and Afghanistan from the beginning.

Embedding is just another facet of this deception.

There is no discussion needed. General McChrystal violated article 88 of the USMC. He could be reassigned, made to retire, or reduced in rank. He resigned but generals are never actually gone and can be recalled any time. Article 88 basically says that no officer of he US military may publicly criticize the civilian leadership. It is a court martial offense if the military so decides to pursue it.
Notice how in Iraq the officers were rarely called into account for the actions of the troops.

Most of us remember Truman firing MacArthur, but FDR fired Stillwell for referiing to Chiang Kai Shek as a midget. Stillwell was corret but he said it publicly and Chiang was our SOB as FDR referred to some foreign leaders. Several generals and admirals were fired or reassigned during WWII. The navy is far quicker to relieve officers who are not living up to their charge. McChrystal may be a good field general but he was not a good command general, same as Patton.
My comment is #260.

I read Lindberg's "War Diaries" recently.  Apparently Britain was so ill-prepared for war that appeasement was the only option at the time.  Lindberg because of his VIP status in the aviation industry got to tour all the plane factories in France, Poland, Russia, England, Germany, and the US before the war.  Germany was mass producing planes while England was hardly making any.

comments.userDisplayName: Alpha Beta Zeta Delta Epsilon Omega
comments.commentBody: Don't we have enough constant changing of language to mean something other than what it means already.  Are we so weak that we cannot change hearts and minds in America so much that we can create a changed understanding amongst people who live here such that they will understand the fundamental benefits and detrimental effects of the use of appeasement. What is true yesterday is not always true tomorrow, at least as far as words go.  Socialism used to be representative of  a large political party in the United States and still is the most common political party in the world and yet we have no such party because we don't even understand as a whole nation the actual meaning of the word, even though we call the greatest benefit and victory of working people who live here Social Security.  Americans understand the concepts of Social Security quite well but politicians have made the word behind its use an unusable word in politics.
The refereeing at the World Cup games in South Africa is only slightly less effective than the security detail at a White House state dinner.
LA Lakers star Kobe Bryant was spotted in South Africa taking in some of the World Cup games.  Either that or his wife insisted he buy her a diamond mine.

At the G-20 global economic summit in Toronto, police have arrested nearly 600 demonstrators.  In honor of former Pres. George W. Bush, when the moderator opened with “Welcome to the G-20”, Pres. Obama shouted, “Bingo!”

After a respectable World Cup showing, the United States team is enjoying a surge of popularity at home. Many Americans can even name a few players, such as "the goalie," "that #8 Lego guy who scored against England," and veteran team leader, Lando Calrissian.
The Gulf of Mexico's "Alex "has strengthened back into a tropical storm. It had weakend into a depression this weekend after learning that Argentina had beaten Mexico 3-1.

Now that the ageless Jamie Moyer has broken MLB's all time record for home runs allowed, he is dealing with a number of jokes about him having given up one of those home runs to Babe Ruth. "Not true" said Moyer, "The Babe couldn't hit me."
